_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: State of Alaska CAA Title V Operating Permit

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Central Compressor Plant (CCP) is classified as NAICS code 211111, Crude Petroleum and Natural Gas Extraction. A prior applicability analysis determined the CCP was not covered by RMP due to the naturally occurring hydrocarbon exemption of the natural gas entering the facility. It was recently recognized that the lean residue gas returning to the CCP from the Central Gas Facility (CGF) is post natural gas processing and, therefore, does not meet the definition of a naturally occurring hydrocarbon mixture.  As such, the volume of lean residue gas at the CCP is subject to the threshold determination requirements of 40 CFR §68 and the gas quantities within the facility have been determined to exceed the thresholds for a flammable mixture due to the current compression pressures.

Description of the included process and regulated substances handled:

The CCP receives raw gas separated from crude oil at the Prudhoe Bay Unit flow stations and the gathering centers.  The raw gas flows through two CCP inlet separators and is then directed to the CGF, where it is treated via two low temperature separation/refrigeration processing trains to produce a lean residue gas.  The lean residue gas is then routed back to CCP where seventeen (17) compressors driven by fifteen (15) turbines compress the gas in two stages to approximately 4,250 psig for injection into the gas cap of the Prudhoe Bay reservoir.  The CCP can compress and inject approximately 7.5 billion standard cubic feet of gas per day.

Gas Compression System:

After natural gas liquids processing at the CGF, the lean residue gas routed back to CCP first undergoes low-stage compression which raises the gas pressure from approximately 600 psig to 2,300 psig.  After the gas has been cooled by a series of fin fan coolers, the gas is further compressed to 4,250 psig and then cooled again.  The resultant high pressure gas is then routed from the CCP to three gas injection drill sites where it is injected into the

reservoir gas cap.

The gas compression system consists of the following equipment and approximate inventories: 
The tandem injection compression with:
¿ Low Pressure Suction Scrubber with approximately 41,200 scf @ 0.055lb/scf  and 73.6% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 1,670 lbs 
¿ High Pressure Suction Scrubber with approximately 33,200 scf @ 0.055lb/scf  and 73.6% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 1,340 lbs
¿ System piping with approximately  52,080 scf @ 0.055lb/scf  and 73.6% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 2,110 lbs

The 1st stage injection compression with:
¿ Low Pressure Suction Scrubber with approximately 459,900 scf @ 0.055lb/scf  and 73.6% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) =  18,610 lbs 
¿ System piping with approximately  321,930 scf @ 0.055lb/scf and 73.6% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) =  13,030 lbs

The 2nd stage injection compression with:
¿ High Pressure Suction Scrubber with approximately 256,000 scf @ 0.055lb/scf and 73.6% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) =  10,360 lbs 
¿ System piping with approximately  179,20 0scf @ 0.055lb/scf and 73.6% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) =  7,250 lbs

The flare system with:
¿ Low Pressure Flare Knockout Drum with approximately 2,500 scf @ 0.055lb/scf and 73.6% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5)=  100 lbs 
¿ High Pressure Flare Knockout Drum with approximately 7,500 scf @ 0.055lb/scf and 73.6% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) =  300 lbs
¿ System piping with approximately  7,000 scf @ 0.055lb/scf and 73.6% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) =  280 lbs
 
Miscellaneous vessels within the gas compression system with:
¿ Hydrocarbon Flash Drum with approximately 5,000 scf @ 0.055lb/scf and 73.6% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) =  200 lbs 
¿ Glycol Receiver Drum with approximately 2,000 scf @ 0.055lb/scf and 73.6% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) =  8

0 lbs
¿ Hydrocarbon Dump Drum with approximately 12,500 scf @ 0.055lb/scf and 73.6% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) =  510 lbs 
¿ Fuel Gas Scrubber with approximately 6,700 scf @ 0.055lb/scf and 73.6% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) =  270 lbs 
¿ System piping with approximately  18,340 scf @ 0.055lb/scf and 73.6% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) =  740 lbs
 
Total residue gas with Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) contain in the compressed gas system is approximately 56,850 lbs.

The basis for the Worst Case Scenario release calculations is a loss of the entire gas compression system. The model used was RMPComp for a Vapor Cloud Explosion to a 1 psi overpressure.

Other Information Required Per 40 CFR 68.155:

CCP's accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are predicated on compliance with OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) standard. The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps include process hazard analysis (PHA) and layer of protection analysis (LOPA). The facility has had no accidents in the past five years from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. The emergency response program was developed consistent with OSHAs Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) and PSM standards, as well as other applicable regulations. Planned changes to improve safety occur through an internal continual improvement processes.

Enclosed modules which house process equipment operated at CCP are equipped with fire suppression systems. In the event of fire, Halon A1 fire suppressant is automatically released to inhibit the chemical reaction of combustion and extinguish the flames. 

Prudhoe Bay has its own professionally-trained fire department which responds and serves as the local
fire department. There is no other jurisdiction providing emergency response at CCP, with the exception of mutual aid provided by the fire departments of other nearby North-Slope Alaska oil fields.
